images.caption: Figure 1:Right: the negative effect that full information has on efficiency in the bargaining game, depending on the player model. Left: the positive effect that sending textual messages has in negotiation games, depending on the player model.

header: Appendix AGame families through the lens of economic literature
Appendix CData Collection from Human Players

images.caption: Figure 2:An example of an instruction screen shown to a human player at the start of a bargaining game.
Figure 3:An example of a proposition screen shown to a human player during his first turn in a bargaining game.
Figure 4:An example of a decision screen shown to a human player during his second turn in a Bargaining game.
Figure 5:An example of a response screen shown to human players during his second turn in a Bargaining game.
Figure 6:An example of an instruction screen shown to a human sellers at the start of a Negotiation game.
Figure 7:An example of a proposition screen shown to human sellers during his first turn in a Negotiation game.
Figure 8:An example of a decision screen shown to human buyers during his first turn in a Negotiation game.
Figure 9:An example of a final quiz screen shown to human sellers at the end of a Negotiation game.
Figure 10:An example of an instruction screen shown to human sellers at the start of a Persuasion game.
Figure 11:An example of a proposition screen shown to human sellers during his first turn in a Persuasion game.
Figure 12:An example of a decision screen shown to human buyers during his first turn in a Persuasion game.
Figure 13:An example of a game over screen shown to human players at the end of a Persuasion game.
